utterances: They spent less than three days driving 2,600 miles from the company's warehouse in Northern Oregon.
Wal-Mart's alternative, the barge, would've taken more than a week.
The truck is specially outfitted to make the long trip and has a moose guard on the front to protect the radiator from run-ins with wildlife and bright moose lights to help the drivers avoid them.
It's also equipped with extra insulation and fuel tank heaters.
And Rod says no matter how cold it gets outside, the fruit and vegetables are kept at the perfect temperature.
I'm pretty proud of that fact, that we can come in here with a 58-degree banana and have gone through 70-below weather.
The men carry survival gear along with the produce.
They have minus 60-degree sleeping bags, safety yellow insulated suits and extra food.
Their route takes them through British Columbia and the Yukon Territory in Canada.
During the eight months of winter, they negotiate snowy mountain passes and have to keep a constant lookout for bison marching along the road.
Rod was part of the first Wal-Mart team that made a run to Alaska two years ago.
